required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Oxygen Saturation Patterns in Post-Op Patients at Risk for Obstructive Sleep Apnea
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Non-Randomized Study of Pulse Oximetry Saturation Patterns in Postoperative Patients at High Risk of Obstructive Sleep Apnea

brief_summary.textblock: This study will include patients who have major surgery and are at risk for or have been diagnosed with sleep apnea. The patients will be monitored the night after surgery for repeating episodes of reduced breathing and oxygen levels. The study will determine if episodes of decreased breathing are reflected in the oxygen monitor.

detailed_description.textblock: There is no further detailed description available.

primary_outcome.measure: Presence of Repetitive Reductions in Nasal Airflow Patterns in the Pulse Oximetry Saturation Trend Data.
primary_outcome.time_frame: 12 hour after released from the recovery room
primary_outcome.description: Number of patients exhibiting the presence of repetitive reductions in airflow patterns in the pulse oximetry trend data collected on subjects

secondary_outcome.measure: Relationship Between the Oxygen Desaturation Patterns and Repetitive Reductions in Nasal Airflow as Measured by Inductance Plethysmography and Nasal Pressure.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 12 hours after discharge form the recovery room
secondary_outcome.description: The number of patients with a positive repetitive reduction in nasal airflow which correlates with positive oxygen desaturation pattern as measured by photoplethysmography sensors.

study_pop.textblock: Patients older than 18 years undergoing thoracic, vascular, head and neck, gynecological, urological, general, orthopedic, and plastic surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients older than 18 years undergoing thoracic, vascular, head and neck, gynecological, urological, general, orthopedic, and plastic surgery.
- Patient must require analgesia and/or sedation postoperatively by any route (intravenous, intramuscular, oral, epidural or intrathecal) for the duration of the study
- Postoperative patients with at least one anticipated over night stay on the general ward with a minimum length of 14 hrs.
- Patients in the ASA category 1-4
- Patients at high risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) as identified by the STOP-Bang Questionnaire or patients previously diagnosed with OSA and not using a CPAP device. (No screening with STOP needed for these patients.)
- Spontaneous breathing
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age less than 18 years
- Patients receiving or anticipated to receive postoperative positive airway pressure support
- Previous allergic/contact reactions to adhesives
- Patients unable to give informed consent
- Pregnancy

participant_flow.recruitment_details: From Feb 2010 to Oct 2010 adults at high risk for obstructive sleep apnea scheduled for general surgery requiring analgesia with an expected over night hospital stay were recruited from the hospital clinic.

group.title: Adult Surgical Patients At Risk for Obstructive Sleep Apnea
group.description: Observational study of adult patients at high risk for obstructive sleep apnea undergoing general surgery requiring analgesia with an expected over night stay. All patients were in this group.

outcome.description: Number of patients exhibiting the presence of repetitive reductions in airflow patterns in the pulse oximetry trend data collected on subjects
outcome.time_frame: 12 hour after released from the recovery room
outcome.population: All patients with complete data were analyzed.

outcome.title: Relationship Between the Oxygen Desaturation Patterns and Repetitive Reductions in Nasal Airflow as Measured by Inductance Plethysmography and Nasal Pressure.
outcome.description: The number of patients with a positive repetitive reduction in nasal airflow which correlates with positive oxygen desaturation pattern as measured by photoplethysmography sensors.
outcome.time_frame: 12 hours after discharge form the recovery room
outcome.population: All patients with a positive repetitive reduction in nasal airflow.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Fran Haury, RRT Research Coordinator, Clinical Affairs
